moves.8... Nxc5 9. dxc5 Bxc5 10. O-O Qd6: Ideas of c6 followed by Bb6 and Bc7.
moves.11. Na4 Bb4: Hoping white will let me play a quick c6...
moves.13... Bb6 14. Nxb6 cxb6: White's backward c3 pawn looks weak.  Also, note the hole white has created on c4.  I begin to arrange for my knight to occupy c4...
moves.15. Bb2 Rc8 16. a3 Qe7: Vacating d6 for the night after Ne4...
moves.18... Nd6 19. Qd1 Nc4: Note the strength of the knight.  It is truly a beautiful piece on c4, preventing white from advancing the weak c3 pawn, and liberating the bishop.  The immediate threat is Nxb2.
moves.20. Rb1 h5: Ideas of Rh6 followed by Qg5 or Rg6...
moves.21. Qd4: Trying to drum up some counterplay...
moves.21... Qg5 22. Rfe1: E4 does look a bit worrisome...
moves.22... Rh6 23. g3: Perhaps the more aggressive e4 was stronger...
moves.23... Rf6 24. Qh4: He wants to trade queens and relieve some of the pressure.  Note the useless bishop on b2 and the defensive rook on b1.
moves.25. f4 Nd2: Threatening Nf3, forking king and queen...
moves.26. Ref1 Ke7: And here he resigned as time ran out.  Black is threatening Nxb1, followed by Rxb1 and Qxb1...
